I've been playing this game for a little over 3 years now and have finally decided to write a review... Most games- if you play them long enough- get boring and tiresome. The people I play with weekly and most of the time daily, have played totals of thousands of hours and yet continue to play weekly/daily. This is because there really can't ever be a round in ND thats the same as another. Each team won't ever be exactly the same, the commanders won't usually be the same, and how the players play in each map will always be different so that you really aren't just going through the motions after hours and hours of gameplay. I know that myself and at least 100-150 other dedicated core players feel the same way. The other reviews of this game that I see are from people who really havent played it all that much and have just taken their first look FPS and RTS aspects. A lot of what they say is correct.. There are definitely areas of ND that need work, and since theres no real developer working on it not much can change.

However, even though there is no actual developer, ND is constantly being improved and tweaked to make gameplay better. This is because of server managers and testers in the community itself who have fixed glitches, improved team balancing, made mods, and have organized ND soooooo much in the past 2 years. Nuclear Dawn was on a downswing and playercounts were at an all time low, but now that there are scheduled events, groups, and stats, things are getting better fast!

So to people who say Nuclear Dawn is dying: It WAS dying, now its only getting better little by little. I highly recommend this game and encourage people to give it a fair chance. reviewText:
First thing's first: I am a passionate lover of FPSRTS genre, having played both Savage and Natural Selection (1&2) for many many hours. So bear that in mind.

So what's Nuclear Dawn? It is a representative of a very rare breed of video games, which combine classic FPS action as a foot soldier and Top Down RTS style commander role. Two teams fight for dominance over critical locations on the map with commanders providing support in form of abilities and buildings which allow forward psawning of reinforcements, ammo/hp regen and defences.

The game itself is fast paced, with several classes to choose from: classic Assault with powerful weaponry, able to take a few hits before going down and iconic thermal vision which negates invisibility, EXO with tons of health and deadly weapons, most effective against buildings, Stealth for general sneaking about, either with knives which can backstab unsuspecing players to sniper and unique sabateur with remote bombs, and lastly a trusty support with lightning-fast firing SMGs, shotgun or a freaking flame thrower. Everyone will find something fun to choose from.

Unofrtunately the game does not have a massive following but there is a good server or two, one in US one in Germany to choose from.

As always remember: there is no middle ground when it comes to FPSRTS matches. You either get a complete stomp of a match, which thankfully does not last too long or you get a very fun and amazing experience, which will keep you coming back for more, day after day.

reviewText:
I've seen this game when it was on sale for 2,49€, and since I found the fps/rts hybrid idea interesting I thought I would give it a try, wouldn't lose much money anyways if it would be bad. What a great decision!
It turns out this is an amazing and well designed co-op game, it is definitely not what one would expect from a 2€ game, it is rather a 20€ game.

The gameplay provides a lot of room for in-depth teamwork with a variety of classes and weapon kits, all suited for different situations, and it is decently balanced. Playing this with friends and good communicating commanders on both teams gives quite an intense outcome. You will be fighting for key positions and pushing back of waves of enemies with commander support, you will get behind enemy lines and assasinate their commander or sabotage their power-grid so your fellow players can rush their positions, you will be going after resource points with your squad to ensure your commander gets resources, ...
Each match is different and highly dynamic, depending on what strategy the commanders and soldiers choose. Playing on the same map is never the same thing!

Which brings me to another point: maps. I can't stop getting surprised at how well the maps are designed in this game. They are full of detail, full of alternative paths, full of hidden places you can use to get an advantage, and the atmosphere is just awesome.

The only problem of this game is its small player base. Most of the time there are one or two full servers of 32 players each, and steamgraph says there are 100 players at peak times/evenings.

If you like the idea of fps/rts hybrid games then you should definitely check this out! It goes on sale very often, and even for 9€ the price is still a joke considering what you get. If you watch the store videos and you think it could be cool, don't hesitate! The game is so much better than it appears in those videos!
It is a shame that this game does not get more attention. Only you can change that! Grab your friends and get Nuclear Dawn! NOW!

I got this game on the 26th from a friend. I played 2 hours that night in single player... I made the mistake the next day of playing multiplayer. 11 hours later I looked up to see that It was almost 10 PM and I'd lost my entire day... There is up to around 3 servers with a respectable amount of people at any given time, so it's not hugely popular, but the sale is bringing in more and more people.

ABOUT THE GAME

Difficulty- It's fairly confusing if you're new to real time strategies to play as the commander, but the tutorials are very helpful. As a troop it's fairly easy to pick up as it's basically counter strike or a newer call of duty game. Technically this fits in the category I guess- the bots are beyond stupid. Half of them just try to jump up to unreachable places until they are shot. This, however, is hilarious.

Variation- The classes are amazing. You can't switch weapons like in call of duty, you use whatever ones come with your class. While some find this annoying, I think it levels out the game and makes it better. There are currently four types of troops with up to three or four classes for each. Changing even just a class can change how you play, or if your team wins or not. And if you get bored of just shooting people, apply to be the commander and play it like a tower defence.

Level of fun- OOOVVEEEERRRRR 9000!!!!!!!!! (sorry not sorry ;D)

Some other pros- There are people who use voice chat to be tactical, and awesome and stuff. I have so far only found one annoying person. The weapons as I said are balanced well. Most servers don't allow friendly fire, but it is an option.

Overall this is an amazing game. How I've been describing it is as a super tactical version of counter strike (YOU CAN BE A FRIKKIN INVISIBLE NINJA) but that doesn't do it justice. Nuclear Dawn is so far my favorite FPS (I like being a drone not the leader personally). It's not just I shot Bob, Bob grenaded me, I knifed George, Jeff shot me... You can be a sneaky ninja, you can be an engineer and repair the buildings, you can flame thrower the crap out of people, you can snipe; you can use a rocket launcher, or a pistol; you can just be a soldier or you can lead an army.

10/10 Wasted my whole day and many more to come.

reviewText:
Nuclear Dawn has some novel ideas and some solid gameplay, but lacks balance and longevity.
I like the idea behind the game... one commander building structures and trying to direct the flow of chaos from within a fortified bunker.  I don't like RTS's because I don't like splitting my attention between resources, structures, and every single unit out there.  Nuclear Dawn puts direction of the troops in the hands of the troops themselves.  Beautiful!  With that out of the way, the RTS commander gameplay is actually nice.

On the field are the grunts of varying classes.  Classes I originally felt played off each other like rock paper scissors with their advantages and disadvantages.  As I played longer, I realized how lopsided things were.
To it's credit, Nuclear Dawn presents 4 general classes, with subclasses within them, allowing for some role overlap but retaining unique perks.  You end up with things like infantry marksmen, stealth sharpshooters, heavy weapons, fire support, mechanical engineers, medics, assassins, etc.  It works well.  Mostly.  Some particular subclasses, like the saboteur, aren't provided enough perks to make them useful.  Same goes for most engineers.

Weapons are a mixed bag, and most of them don't feel robust and exciting.  Sniper rifles are extremely jittery, Assault rifle recoil is insane, and grenades are incredibly overpowered.  The big huge armored guys carrying structure destroying weapons are either a rocket launcher that feels like its shooting needles or a big huge square tube that fizzles out a thin beam of blue energy that reminds me of a bug zapper, not a devastator.  The stealth class armblades just whiff through the air even when hitting someone.. no gusto, no grit.  And pistols, my god the pistols.. everyone carries one and every single one is like a sniper rifle.. it seems a common skill to get a headshot from long range with it and it's pretty much an instant kill unless you're heavily armored.

People move quickly.  Circle strafe fights are everywhere, and it all amounts to who can land a headshot first because without it, killing anyone takes forever.  I've played games where my stealth ninja class was chasing a huge lumbering Exo-armored enemy... and I had to run full speed just to keep pace with him.  What the hell is that??  Exo is supposed to be slow and vulnerable.  As assault you have a vision mode that reveals cloaked stealths, but even when you can see them a mile off coming straight at you, sidestepping is so fast that it's hard to draw a bead on him before he runs right up to you and stabs you to death.  It feels like a bad Monty Python and the Holy Grail moment.

The push-pull feel of games is good, but is heavily reliant on team-oriented players.  People who can work towards a goal.  People who can hold a line of defense, even if the kill count could be higher elsewhere.  Eventually the game will tip heavily in favor of one team or another.  From this point, it can take 15-20 minutes before the game actually ends, all while the losing side gets spawn-killed repeatedly.  This is stupid.  The designers smartly added a surrender option, but only the commander can issue it, and most either don't know or don't care because while their team is spawning and dying in droves, they are in their bunker watching it all fall apart, trying to get turret kills until finally the bunker is destroyed.

Nuclear Dawn can also use bots.  Either in a single-player-esque mode, or to fill out online servers.  Unfortunately they are stupid.  I mean stand in place doing nothing stupid.  I mean won't follow basic commander directions stupid.  I mean don't react to bullets stupid.  I mean 10 years ago Perfect Dark Zero stupid.

Servers are scattered and few.  Players all cluster on one server.  Due to the XP and levelling system, veterans will have an advantage over newcomers in quite a drastic way.  That makes getting into the game harder.  I think it's accurate to say this is a dying game in it's twilight years.  Devs have stopped working on it.

The graphics aren't bad, the ideas aren't bad, it kind of comes close to being good.  But it isn't.  It's a shame because with proper care, this could have introduced a seriously fresh way to play both FPS and RTS.  I really wanted to enjoy this more, but it simply can't deliver any sustainable enjoyment, only disappointment and frustration.
Don't play this.  In a short while, the farmer will come out to shoot this lame horse.

reviewText:
Nuclear Dawn is one of the best mash ups of FPS and RST currently available on Steam.  It is my impression that the only contender in thei genre on steam is Natural Selection 2, so i will do a little compare/contrast at the end of this.

The good:

-Excelent RTS gameplay.  UI is basic, and at times a little clunky, but in general it gets the job done for both macro and micro management of building, upgrades, and resources.  The biggest problem is relying on your soldiers to defend your structures and get you resources.

-Decent FPS class based combat.  Each class has thier strengths, and thier weaknesses.  Weapons are well balanced across classes and teams. Certian mechanics can be difficult if you are used to more FPS centric games, and getting used to having to rely on someone to get you better weapons and spawn points can be tough, but in gerneral the FPS gameplay is rewarding.

-A Great community.  The people who play this game LOVE it.  They set up events on popular severs, help out new people, and are very communicative.

The bad:

-Small base of players. Time has taken its toll on the number of active players.  At peak times there is often a server of 30 players or so, but other than that there are very few people playing.

-Small selection of maps.  Although the community has done thier best to make a wider selection of maps, there are still a very limited amount compared to FPS centeric and RTS centeric games.

***Natural Selection 2 vs. Nuclear Dawn***

Natural Selection 2 has 2 radically different sides.  Although this creates some more variety, thier strengths are appearant at different points throughout a match, which makes the game much more difficult to balance.  At this point in time I would say that for balancing reasons alone Nuclear Dawn is the better game.

Nuclear Dawn has considerably larger maps than Natural Selection 2.  This allows for more strategy for each commander, expecially when compared to Natural Selection's closed corridors and small rooms.

Both games have equivilent FPS gameplay, with the exception that NS2 is only class based for one of the teams.  The other team can custimize thier loadouts (shotguns midgame, grenade launchers/flamethrowers late game, exo suits end game), but thier overall stats are the same.

Nuclear Dawn blows the pants off NS2 when it comes to RTS UI.  Because the 2 sides have very similar buildings, the developers were able to keep the key bindings for each side's buildings the same, so it is very easy to play as commander for either side.  This is not the case for NS2.


Overall, if you like FPS, or RTS this game is worth a try.  Make sure to sign up with the community groups so you know when everyone else is playing.

A final note:  This game, like many team based FPS, really requires a mic.  You can still be an effective team member if you don't (there are in-game voice commands), but I can assure you that at least once every game you will wish you had it to call out enemy locations accuratly, or request supplies in a very specivic spot.  For the RTS element a mic is a must.

reviewText:
I love this game!  I've never played anything like it.  A very fun mixture of FPS and RTS.  Two commanders handle the RTS part, the rest play FPS, however, it is up to the FPS players to defend and repair the assets that the commander deploys for them as they work their way to the enemy base.

Attacking players can tactically and strategically decide which assets to take out first:  Power relay, turrets, spawn points, supply stations.  In addition to destoying enemy assets and defending your own, you must fight over resource points.

The infiltrator has a cloak, and there's lots of fun to be had there.  The backstab is very rewarding, and you can also cloak to the enemy base and assassinate the commanderr in his bunker, and then hang out on the base and delay his commander efforts.

Each class has a special ability, and each primary weapon choice alters your secondary gear as well.  Each major weapon can utilize a Gizmo, which enhances the weapon.  If you like challenges, this game requires a lot of play time to work up the ranks and unlock various enhancements.

Lots of fun to be had here with a unique experience.  Don't miss out!  You definitely want to be able to say you played this one, and if you're a developer, you can use this for inspiration to make a new game in this genre.

This is great game with a lot of scope for fun, a good old 'kill and die' spawn fest fun session on steroids. Under good command this game delivers. A tip of the hat to the legendary Comms, (Gay_for_Ellis, [TAU] Black Cat, Muon, Tea, Coeffus, The_Bolt, MitchellJames and JHolman to name but a few) for showing good team handling, sound strategies and outstanding patience while guiding us to glory (or defeat, but there can be only one..). The method of matched classes makes for good even play with each class having nuances worthy of investigation. For aussies, this game is always played on US or European servers so your ping will be high - from Victoria I average 250 in the USA and 350 in Europe, but this is no obstacle to those dedicated to enjoying good team-based gameplay. The sessions, when full, are complex and engaging where changing class quickly can win or lose the match. There is a small problem with inexperienced comms taking the helm but a good soldier follows orders and I'm here to help the team win. 3 thumbs up to the devs - not many flaws here...

I wanted to write a good review and a bad review but I can only do one so ... this is the bad one underneath..

Back during the Beta, people that got the game were interested in game play but a few days after, Cowardice took most of the players' ego and then never let go. Exo-whoring; the propensity for the more gutless to gang up in armour - pity that meant most of the teams. Team-stacking; The choice of champions - where everyone with high rank stacked on the same team totally outclassing the lower ranked with persistent perks. reviewText:
Nuclear Dawn is a fun little FPS that reminds me immediately of games like Timesplitters, TF2, Dirty Bomb, Insurgency, and ESPECIALLY Unreal Tournament. It's a class-based shooter with various abilities available as you level up your character. There are initially four different classes, and each team has a Commander (with various upgrades including armor, ammo, etc). Each class has three drastically different loadout sets with various weapons in each one. This is where the TF2 influence shines clear through.

I mentioned Unreal Tournament, as well. Unreal Tournament is one of the most well-respected shooters released, and when I compare this game to it, I feel the need to explain myself. The pacing of both games is identical, with a mad dash to objectives resulting in very short life spans with quick spawn times. This allows you to filter in and out of combat with ease, allowing for you to change classes or weapons as needed during combat.

Really fun game in segments, but if it has a weakness, it would be in map structure. Nothing really sticks out in any of the maps, and they mostly seem to be several small rooms loosely connected to eachother, for the most part. Granted, this can be said of most multiplayer FPS games. Regardless, I don't think it's enough of a weakness to merit a poor review, so I'll say wait for a sale, or grab it right now in the Humble Bundle (Feb 25th, 2016)!

reviewText:
Nuclear Dawn is, as it's name tells, a game at the dawn of a nuclear war. If it, mostly an FPS but there are a few different ways to play the game :

1- You're a simple soldier, on the field. Like in most of the other FPSs, you target an enemy and shoot him down (or he does it). You can choose to have either a shotgun, a sniper or an assault rifle and can detect enemy camos.
2- You're an assassin, on the field. You can make yourself invisible (become a camo) and stab your enemies from behind OR you just shoot them down with a sniper OR you use some bombs, kinda C4s ('cause you can activate them from a long distance).
3- You are a BADASS tank with either a BADASS machine-gun or a SUPER BADASS rocket launcher. And like most of the heavy tanks' infantry, you're slow as ****.
4- You are THE man of the game. You're the commander. You build stuff, as if you were a player of some of the tower defense games but, also, you choose either to upgrade your team, help them while on the field or just go with them.


Just seeing this, you (should) guess it's not an FPS like all the others. This one is a mix between Call Of Duty and tower defense's games such as World Of Empire or Plant VS Zombies while being much better.




Now, let's check out the good and bad things of this game...

GOOD
- multiplayer and solo player available,
- not bad graphics,
- an easy controllable shooter, even with a keyboard,
- a simple but helpful tutorial (to learn of to really play, even though I never even dated to finish it),
- no stupid players, just a few games entirely made of bots,
- the online games are never (well, since I started playing) full.

BAD
- some online games can be so long and, sometimes, start to get you bored,
- some commanders can't make your team win and the online servers don't have so much players,
- you need to know how to really play an FPS.


So, yeah. You really need to learn how to play on FPSs ;)

reviewText:
I have always been into FPS games and RTS games, and the thought of mixing the two I was a little fickle about, but i have to hand it to the developers, they really put it in a way where i can play this game for hours straight and not get bored. First i should go over the pros of this game, and trust me there are plenty.
Now this game treats the RTS and the FPS as two completly corresponding things. You need your Commander (The one player who has the RTS view) and he needs you. As a normal FPS player, you go around accomplishing objectives and killing the enemy team when possible. However if the Commander feels there is something you should all focus on, he may simply issue a comand, and you can see a position in which he wants to defend or attack. The commander also is responsible for building important structures, such as Teleporters, Supply Stations, Armorys and Artilery cannons, and better yet the Artilery cannons have the option for the commander to own them entirley, or for his troops to be able to call in for some support. This adds yet another unique combination of RTS and FPS.
A couple of things I found slightly discouraging were the fact that some kits are locked until the commander forks over the resources to reasearch them for your team, and once he does, then you can acess them, but until then you will just have to stare at that Rocket launcer, or grenade launcher until your commander decides he wants you to have it. Another things i find distasteful is the lack of weapon kits, 3 per class(Including the one you need to unlock), yet all of them seem fitting so its not actually too much of a problem. an upside to this is a new player will have the acess to the same weapons as any veteran, which I enjoy, because in many FPS games I have played, veterans usually have an advantage with far better weapons than new players.
All in all I would completly recommend Nuclear Dawn to anyone who likes FPS games and RTS games. It beautifully mixs the two and deserves far more fame than it has, I feel if the developers had added more guns and structures this game would be all the rage same as games like Call of Duty and Battlefield, but that is just my opinion, so i will leave it to you to form your own opinion of this game.
Have Fun

reviewText:
At first I thought this game would be quite complex, but turns out this is one of the easiest FPS games you could find and a really good one at it too.

The FPS part has multiple classes who balance themselves very well, Some have high health and are slow heavy weaponed and others have low health but are extremely fast and can cloak themselves to be invisible.
You start the game, join a server and there you go. The game has a RTS element meaning there is a player playing the role of  a Commander who gives you orders and sets points to spawn and supply units and all needed support.
So if you don't want to run around not knowing what to do, or feel like learning a lot of strategy, this will help you at playing if you follow orders and help others.

The RTS part is even better, being a commander you can communicate orders that people might or might not follow. You set up a network of power units, supply units and spawnpoints, those are bought with credits you get by your team capturing points. It's not too complicated but can take some time getting a winning strategy and depends hugely on the players playing.

Overall it's surely is one of my favorite games, favorite FPS and is the one I play when I don't want to think too much, just sit back and follow orders and contribute my part to the team.

reviewText:
If you'd like to hear my full thoughts on Nuclear Dawn, you can listen to the episode on Game Hoard Podcast[soundcloud.com]

Nuclear Dawn pits two teams against each other as they vie for control points and try to push their offensive into the other team's base. One player on each team takes the role of the commander and views the battlefield from an overhead view, effectively playing the game as an RTS. The commander groups players into squads, issues orders, constructs buildings, and lends battlefield assistance. Meanwhile other players can choose between four classes: assault, exo (i.e. heavy), support, and stealth. Within each class there are also different loadouts available.

What makes Nuclear Dawn great is that it really does play well as both a shooter and a strategy game. No team can succeed without both the commander and the other players doing a good job and working together. I was surprised by how much being a commander actually felt like playing an RTS.

On the negative side of things, the whole aesthetic of the game is fairly generic and uninteresting. It's basically all just slightly futuristic war-torn gray/brown cities and cookie cutter soldiers without that well-defined of a setting. I found that it made it a bit difficult to learn the map layouts since everything just looked so similar.

Also problematic is that building very often get in the way of the commander's view and I wish that they would have been made transparent for the commander. It often means that you have to do a fair bit of manipulating the camera to see the action.

Overall, Nuclear Dawn is a great competitive online experience. While the game is a bit old, I could still always find at least one server with a fair number of players, so it's still worth getting for that. If you want a game to play online that takes some time to get into and does something a little more interesting than your typical team deathmatch, I can definitely recommend Nuclear Dawn.

reviewText:
Nuclear Dawn is another source engine based mod that made into a full game. And, it is one of the better ones.

First, lets see what is so good in this game. The mechanics are great. The use of weapons feel natural and easy to handle. The arsenal is also acceptable. Core maps are well designed allowing multiple playing styles and tactics to use. The classes felt balanced and competitive against each other. There are some unlockable customization options also which can be used to earn a little bit of advantage, but they are not that much they could ruin the fun. Strategy elements are well implemented requiring a good commander and teamwork.
I also need to mention the worse parts of the game. The content is somewhat less than it would be ideal, but since release the developers made tools to aid the community, just before they abandoned the game for good. But, you can now have some good custom built maps and stuff from workshop. However, now comes the worst aspect of the game, its current playerbase. To be able to play this game ideally, you would need one applicable commander and at least five people in your team. Also, teamwork is necessary for success. Now, when the game has only a minimal amount of regular players you can hardly play a match in normal circumstances. Bots can be deployed in both online and offline play, but they are only half-solution. Also, they cannot control the constructions, so someone will still need to take care of the commander duties.

This game had its time in the competitive multiplayer scene, but it is surely one of those games that should not be forgotten due the amount of fun that it can give those who really spend time and effort to it.

My Opinion:
OVERALL: 7.5/10
Graphics: 8/10
Gameplay: 8/10
Sound: 7/10
Replay Value: 7/10

reviewText:
Interesting concept, and a rather interesting game, but it fails on the practical approach.

First of all, the FPS segment is nice enough. Could have been more developed but I feel it's on pair with the most FPS games. However the RTS part... That's the deal breaker. It's interesting. It's new. But it mostly feels like a chore... You don't really control the troops since those are players who most of time won't understand you and their role in the greater scheme of things. So in the end all you seem to do is build stuff to protect yourself and support them... You're not the commander, you're their hoe.

Finally, just like every other indie online game servers might be empty most of the time, and you have to play with other players... Don't take this in the wrong direction, but the thing is this game relies far more on your team and commander than the regular FPS due the RTS elements, so having some players won't just cut it.

But all in all I guess I should still recommend this game. Despite being a somewhat failure, it tried a new and bold approach on both genres. So play it if you're interested in learning a lesson and try out something different.

Engineers should be able to construct buildings. Commanders don't often put them in tactical positions.

I was lucky enough to have access to battle zone II, if you know the game then it saves me the trouble of explaining how 'similar' or 'different' it was to Nuclear Dawn  but if not. It was and still is very 'similar' but 'different' to Nuclear Dawn. Google the game if you're interested.

At the moment of writing this review, umm... give or take two minute's. I literally counted 7 player's including me, the 6 on a new york server and I starring in horror, remembering the previous reviews about the game.

reviewText: Nuclear Dawn is at the end of its life. Even though there are many servers that are running, only one of them seems to be active with human players at any time. The problem with that server is that it's located in Europe, and the ping is around 200 or higher for me. The maps and environments look great. The futuristic science fiction aesthetic works really well with the weapons and special abilities. Each of the four classes offer a varied and atypical approach to combat. The unlocks also seem to help you through the battles, even though it takes a while to get them through the experience system. In addition, there are many weapon kit loadouts available to all classes; making gameplay very different through the combination of classes, loadouts, and unlocks. Resource capturing can be extremely fun while trying to dodge bullets from enemy fire, and if you have a good commander, you will be in an excellent position to push forward against the enemy's main base. Speaking of the commander feature, this can also make or break your enjoyment of Nuclear Dawn. Commanders require experience and know-how of the game. From extensive knowledge of map locations, to the much needed in-depth tactical familiarity required at different times throughout the match, and the placement of necessary strategic structures around the map. Even though the game allows for players to start a mutiny vote against the commander, finding a good player to fill that role can sometimes be problematic. The commander must also be caring, as she or he should not approach the job as a one person show. This commander mechanic is very similar to the one found in Natural Selection 2. While all of these features sound as though they meld together an amazing, thoroughly enjoyable gaming experience, the sad fact that the multiplayer community is basically dead defeats all chances of greatness and playability. Unless you are specifically in Europe, Nuclear Dawn simply cannot be enjoyed to its full potential. Its solitary European populated server whose ping is well in the 200s makes this game completely unplayable for me. Even if you are in Europe, there will be many times that you will join the one server, and it will only have three or four people playing. This is a multiplayer online only game without a community. Maybe the upcoming update that will supposedly also add native Linux support will help.\n\nNuclear Dawn is okay.

reviewText:
So far, I can only rate this game based on the infantry training section. I'll revise later if I'm somehow to blame for the lack of information provided.

Now, in training, the assault class is straightforward enough to not be a problem. Point and shoot, use goggles for seeing stealth. Straight to the point, no questions, no confusion.

Exo training is where things started getting vague. I'm told that I'm heavy, with a lack of mobility, and am told to use the minigun to eliminate some targets, followed by the class special with lockdown. Right after this, I'm told about a siege weapon, and told to destroy the target using an M95. BUT the problem is that there's NO EXPLANATION about which button to press to get to the M95, or whether I need to change kits, or how to change kits. Nothing is given whatsoever, so I was left to using the chaingun to destroy the remaining structures. I'm not sure if I'm missing it in the interface somewhere or whether there's no option to customize as a level 0, but either way, it's literally impossible that I should or could know this information. They need to specify what the hell I need to do and what button or section does it.

Stealth again was straightforward as far as the training, but I can speak as to the difficulty of the class regarding any of the kits since they don't train you with anything but the generic first kit. Which is also frustrating, since I would like to test out each of the sub classes. THAT'S WHAT TRAINING IS SUPPOSED TO BE FOR.

Lastly, support training, which seems like it should be pretty easy to learn, if it weren't for not being able to find how to change kits. I'm told to drop a health kit, then to destroy an enemy supply station with my torch, followed by repairing a friendly one. The problem is that I'm put into the medic kit, then not told how to change to the engineer kit. Effectively making my tutorial an impossible cockblock that can't be bypassed.

So, in summary, more explanation is needed in the training, as well as a more in depth tutorial on kits and at least basics of how to switch between them. Especially in the training sections, where we're learning how to play the damn game for the first time.

UPDATE: I just wanted to say to the people who have down voted my review, can you honestly tell me you prefer Source over Unreal or idTech?  Can you name a single thing that Source does better than other engines?  I ask because the only reason I can see to down vote my review is my stance on Source (which has such a cult following it'd make Taylor Swift jealous - and it's equally lackluster compared to its competition).  Nothing else I said here is really debatable.  The tutorial IS broken, the achievement IS unobtainable, and the crouch/sniper issues remain.  Even if this was done in Unreal it'd still get a negative review from me.  Of course, then I doubt these issues would happen in the first place.  Anyhow, onward to my review for anyone who still cares to read it...

This is yet another game held back by the Source Engine.  Yes, you read that right.  I said it.

The truth is that the Source Engine - much beloved by (nearly) all - is an outdated relic that gained a sterling reputation in 2004 as a good engine - and then nobody ever through to question that again.  Meanwhile, Unreal Enginer 3 (or really even UE2), idTech 4/5, or something like Unity are now far superior in every measurable way to Source Engine.

If this game has been on Unreal Engine 2 (or better yet, 3) I wouldn't be uninstalling it right now.  But yeah, the engine ruins the game here.  If anyone wants specific notations, here ya go:

The FPS/RTS hybrid model works brilliantly in this game.  I have played actual RTS games that weren't this good even on the RTS side, the the FPS is your standard near-future military shooter.

However, this is where source starts to rear its ugly head.  Unlike every other FPS engine in existance, you cannot stop walking mid-step.  This makes for awkward movement that feels like you're controlling a 9 legged elephant rather than a human, and makes taking any semblence of aim while your character is moving impossible.  This movement is just like TF2, another Source Engine title, and I can't stand it there either.

The sniper rifles lack variable zoom.  While not terribly uncommon for sniper rifles in modern FPS games to lack variable zoom, this is still a mark against it, and once again this is made worse by the use of Source Engine.  Whereas other games might allow you to crouch and stay there, Source forces you to constantly hold the crouch key to remain crouched.  And unlike other engines where this is the case, the game lacks even an option to make crouch a toggle.  This means you're stuck quickscoping everything, or else not playing a sniper, because the standard Assault Rifle is accurate, when hip-fired, to almost the same range as your sniper rifle is zoomed.  Since you can't really crouch and you have the lowest health, you are left 100% dependant on your cloak just to survive at all with the stealth kit - and it takes 3x as long to recharge as it does to discharge.  Which would be fine, if you could more easily crouch behind cover...which you can't, because Source.

The tutorial is broken.  While the RTS tutorial works fine, there are two points in the FPS tutorial where the game is supposed to forcibly change your loadout for you...and it doesn't.  The first time you are playing the heavy" class and it's supposed to change your chaingun for a rocket launcher

reviewText:
Nuclear Dawn is the first game to offer a full FPS and RTS experience, within a single gameplay model, without crippling or diluting either side of the game.
As a soldier, explore war-torn post-apocalyptic landscapes, modelled on modern cities, and take the fight to your enemies as armoured, assault or stealth infantry, using various weapons across ten distinct load-outs to accomplish your objectives. The first person shooter action in Nuclear Dawn is hard, fast and unforgiving, with weapons that rely on skill and tactics more than on twitch reflexes and map memorization.

Then, take Nuclear Dawn above the action, and play as the commander. Organize your fellow players in squads, and assign them to tactical objectives. Plan the resource routes for your army, and production of your structures for forward deployment. Exploit the terrain and resource point locations to block your enemies’ advance, and crush their plans in an iron fist. Research and implement new technologies to give your soldiers the edge on the battlefield, and set up forward bases to lead the assault on your enemies, with a full complement of defensive and offensive structures to choose from, to build your perfect fortress.

reviewText:
For some reason, I've always had a weak spot for source mods. Some of my favorites being Zombie Master, Synergy, and this game. I remember playing the free weekend for this game around 2011 or 2012 and remembering how much I liked it. The gameplay is pretty cool, combines elements of both FPS and RTS, the commander gets an RTS Eagle-Eye view and can place a bunch of structures and so forth. The FPS gameplay is your standard shooter, point crosshairs at baddies, destroy enemy structures and so forth.

However, one thing really bothers me about this game: How come there aren't that many people playing? The game is fun, and with the addition of trading cards and Steamworks support, you'd think the game would be a little more popular. That's not to say there's absolutely nobody playing, while the community is small, it seems to be a very dedicated one. You should be able to makes a few friends pretty fast on here.

The game creates a nice twist by incorporating RTS elements into the mix, anyone who is a fan of team-based, squad combat shooters should feel right at home with this game. For $10, you can't go wrong.

For some reason, I've always had a weak spot for source mods. Some of my favorites being Zombie Master, Synergy, and this game. Come Back to this Really Fun RTS HybridAs hybrid RTS games are generally mediocre at best, I wasn't expecting much when I spent $2.50 on this few years' old game, but holy ♥♥♥♥ - this is a lot of fun.
There aren't many servers, but there really should be. I've got 1000+ hours into TF2 and I could see spending that much time in this Nuclear Dawn if it had a more active community. The replayability is huge, and with mods there's really no ceiling to how immersive this game could grow to be. Why? Because it appeals to a broader base and it's excitingly multi-dimensional. It's a great shooter, but if you aren't in the mood for gunfighting, you can command, and commanding people instead of sprites adds a whole different dimension. If you care about your soldiers as a commander, you can support one another's goals to huge success. Though I consider it an extremely desireable feature, the Achilles' Heel of this game is its dependence on leadership.
Even more than the Battlefield series, not having a commander, or following an ineffective one, greatly undermines the team's chances to win. The soldiers rely on the commander providing upgrades, transport, and supplies they need to stay competitive.
On the ground, gameplay feels a lot like Battlefield built over the Source engine, which is essentially what it is. Also a bonus, IMO. Squads, lots of adaptations to classes and unlocks, and pretty enjoyable from a lot of angles. If you're a purist in any one area, this may not be your bag. It's  not perfect at anything, but it's really good at almost everything.
I'd love to see Nuclear Dawn make a comeback. I think this game really deserves a second look.

I got the game as a gift in the Steam Christmas Sale 2011 and played it for the first time about half a year later, because I really didn't know what I would get.
Nuclear Dawn combines the elements of a squad-based shooter like Battlefield with the elements of an RTS: One player of each team becomes the commander, who can build defensive and offensive structures like turrets or power stations, while his teammates have to control ressource points and exterminate the opposing team.

The balancing on each map is outstanding and the leveling system with new perks is rewarding, but you have to put a lot of effort in it before it pays off; maybe a bit too much regarding the small rewards.
But it's fun for a quick battle and the graphics look good, too.

[TL;DR: Nuclear Dawn is fun but lacks frequent playerbase to keep it fun and AI is backwards.]

Nuclear Dawn is certainly a well paced shooter with the means of having a RTS side if that was more of your thing. It's not the prettiest graphics wise as it does show a certain amount of age but I do like what it was attempting. The FPS side of things are fairly simple to understand and RTS side, it's not too hard to understand.

But now onto the problems that I found with the game.

First of all, the AI. It was a few patches ago that they introduced the AI System and while it mean you can play by yourself, the game originally was designed for Player vs Player interactions. And as such, the AI opponent will never build any buildings and will just simply run endlessly at your base, guns blazing and probably would only win if you decide to quit.

Your AI teammates are just as thick and one time while I was stuck in my command chair, I ordered my underlings to capture a crucial point that was 5 feet away from the spawner. They gave me the affirmmative and I waited until they moved into the point. Now it takes three to capture this crucial location and there were five of them that had used the spawner. Only one of the bots made it into the capture range. The rest stopped against a knee high fence and stared at their lonely comrade with maybe a longing glance. And nothing I did afterwards could make them move and the enemy AI was pressumably doing the same thing somewhere else as they were notably absent.

The maps are fun enough, albeit a bit small feeling if you're a seasoned RTS player. FPS wise, the indoor areas are great for firefights but when it comes to fighting outside, things can be a bit one sided if the enemy commander can just hail nukes on you and insta-kill you from the get-go.

It's a good game, don't take things the wrong way, but the AI do need some improvements. At least they don't complain that you're hacking when you headshot dominate them the whole game.
